                                            • Exercise 3.E

                                            1

                                            Suppose T is a function from V to W. The graph of T is the subset of V×W defined by

                                            graph of T={(v,Tv)∈V×W:v∈V}

                                            Prove that T is a linear map if and only if the graph of T is a subspace of V×W.

                                            Proof: That T is a linear map means T(λa+b)=λTa+Tb for any a,b∈V,λ∈F. Thus for (λa,Tλa) and (b,Tb) in graph of T, let v=λa+b and we have

                                            (λa,Tλa)+(b,Tb)=(λa+b,Tλa+Tb)=(λa+b,T(λa+b))=(v,Tv)

                                            which is in graph of T, this means the graph of T is a subspace of V×W. Reverse the steps above we can prove the other direction.

                                            2

                                            Suppose V1,…,Vm are vector spaces such that V1×⋯×Vm is finite-dimensional. Prove that Vj is finite-dimensional for each j=1,…,m.

                                            Proof: Assume we have Vk being infinite dimensional with k between 1 to m, set dim⁡(V1×⋯×Vm)=n, then since Vk is infinite dimensional, we can find n+1 linearly independent vectors v1,…,vn+1∈Vk. Let 0j be the additive identity of Vj, and let

                                            ui=(01,…,0k−1,vi,0k+1,…,0m)∈V1×⋯×Vm,i=1,…,n+1

                                            then u1,…,un+1 is a linearly independent set with length >n, which is a contradiction.

                                            3

                                            Give an example of a vector space V and subspaces U1,U2 of V such that U1×U2 is isomorphic to U1+U2 but U1+U2 is not a direct sum.

                                            Solution: Let V=F∞, let U1={(x1,x2,0,0,…) and U2=V, then U1+U2=V and obviously this is not a direct sum. Define a map T:U1×U2→V as

                                            T((x1,x2,0,0,…),(y1,y2,y3,…))=(x1,x2,y1,y2,y3,…)

                                            then T is injective and surjective. Thus U1×U2 is isomorphic to U1+U2.

                                            4

                                            Suppose V1,…,Vm are vector spaces. Prove that L(V1×⋯×Vm,W) and L(V1,W)×⋯×L(Vm,W) are isomorphic vector spaces.

                                            Proof: Let Ti∈L(Vi,W) for i=1,…,m, define a map T from V1×⋯×Vm to W as follows: for v=(v1,…,vm)∈V1×⋯×Vm, let Tv=∑i=1mTivi. We can see that for u=(u1,…,um)∈V1×⋯×Vm and a∈F we have

                                            T(au+v)=T(a(u1,…,um)+(v1,…,vm))=T(au1+v1,…,aum+vm)=∑i=1mTi(aui+vi)=∑i=1maTiui+∑i=1mTivi=aTu+Tv

                                            so T∈L(V1×⋯×Vm,W). Let S be the map such that S(T1,…,Tm)=T, we need to prove S is bijective.

                                            Let T=0, then Tv=0 for any v=(v1,…,vm)∈V1×⋯×Vm, this means ∑i=1mTivi=0 for any choice of v1,…,vm with each vi∈Vi, thus we must have Ti=0 for i=1,…,m. This means S is injective. Also, Let T be any element in L(V1×⋯×Vm,W), then for Tv=w∈W for v=(v1,…,vm)∈V1×⋯×Vm, define Ti∈L(Vi,W) for i=1,…,m with the following method:

                                            Ti(vi)=T(0,…,0,vi,0,…,0)=T(v⋅ei),vi∈Vi

                                            with ei∈Fm that has 1 in the ith position and 0 otherwise. Having defined T1,…,Tm, we can see that

                                            S(T1,…,Tm)v=∑i=1mTivi=∑i=1mT(v⋅ei)=T(∑i=1mei)⋅v=Tv

                                            so S(T1,…,Tm)=T and S is surjective.

                                            5

                                            Suppose W1,…,Wm are vector spaces. Prove that L(V,W1×⋯×Wm) and L(V,W1)×⋯×L(V,Wm) are isomorphic vector spaces.

                                            Proof: Let Ti∈L(V,Wi) for i=1,…,m. Define a map T from V to W1×⋯×Wm by Tv=(T1v,…,Tmv) for v∈V. It is easy to see that T is linear. Let φ be the map such that φ(T1,…,Tm)=T.

                                            Let T=0, then Tv=(0,…,0) for ∀v∈V, thus Tiv=0 on V and Ti=0 for i=1,…,m, so φ is injective. Let T be any linear map from V to W1×⋯×Wm, then Tv=(w1,…,wm) with wi∈Wi. Let Ti be defined with Tiv=wi=Tv⋅ei, with ei∈Fm that has 1 in the ith position and 0 otherwise, then φ(T1,…,Tm)v=(T1v,…,Tmv)=Tv, so we can see φ is surjective.

                                            6

                                            For n a positive integer, define Vn by

                                            Vn=V×⋯×V⏟n times

                                            Prove that Vn and L(Fn,V) are isomorphic vector spaces.

                                            Proof: For v=(v1,…,vn)∈Vn, Define Tv:Fn→V with

                                            Tv(a1,…,an)=a1v1+⋯+anvn

                                            It is easy to verify Tv is linear. Let φ(v1,…,vn)=Tv. If Tv=0, then a1v1+⋯+anvn=0 for any choice of scalars a1,…,an, thus let ai=1,aj=0,j≠j we can see vi=0 for i=1,…,n, this means φ is injective. Let T be any element in L(Fn,V), let vi=Tei with ei∈Fn that has 1 in the ith position and 0 otherwise, then for v=(Te1,…,Ten) we have

                                            Tv(a1,…,an)=a1Te1+⋯+anTen=T(a1e1+⋯+anen)=T(a1,…,an)

                                            this means T=Tv=φ(Te1,…,Ten), so φ is surjective.

                                            7

                                            Suppose v,x are vectors in V and U,W are subspaces of V such that v+U=x+W. Prove that U=W.

                                            Proof: If v=x there is nothing to prove. Suppose v≠x, then v−x is a nonzero vector in V and for any u∈U, we have v+u∈v+U=x+W, thus there exists some w∈W such that v+u=x+w, this means v−x+u=w, since U is a subspace, 0∈U, so if we let u=0 in the equation above, we get v−x=w∈W, this means u=w−(v−x)∈W since W is also a subspace. Thus we get U⊆W, similarly we can prove W⊆U.

                                            8

                                            Prove that a nonempty subset A of V is an affine subset of V if and only if λv+(1−λ)w∈A for all v,w∈A and all λ∈F.

                                            Proof: If A is an affine subset of V, then A=x+U for some x∈V and U a subspace of V. Let v,w∈A, then v=x+u and w=x+u′ for some u,u′∈U, since U is a subspace, we have λu+(1−λ)u′∈U for any λ∈F.

                                            λv+(1−λ)w=λ(x+u)+(1−λ)(x+u′)=x+λu+(1−λ)u′∈A

                                            Conversely, A is nonempty means we can find an vector v∈A⊆V, let U={a−v:a∈A}, we show U is a subspace of V:

                                            First 0=v−v∈U.

                                            Second, if c∈F, then given u∈U we have u=a−v for some a∈A. Thus cu=ca−cv=ca−(c−1)v−v, since a∈A,v∈A and ca−(c−1)v=ca+(1−c)v∈A, we see cu∈U.

                                            Finally, let u,u′∈U, then we have u=a−v,u′=a′−v for some a,a′∈A, thus

                                            12(u+u′)=12(a+a′−2v)=12a+12a′−v∈U

                                            then u+u′=2(12(u+u′))∈U.

                                            Thus U is a subpsace of V, and obviously we have A=v+U.

                                            9

                                            Suppose A1 and A2 are affine subsets of V. Prove that the intersection A1∩A2 is either an affine subset of V or the empty set.

                                            Proof: When A1∩A2≠∅, we select any v,w∈A1∩A2. If it is not possible to make v≠w, then A1∩A2 consists of only one vector v for some v∈V, thus is an affine subset since {v}=v+{0}. Now suppose it is possible to choose v≠w, we have v,w∈A1 and v,w∈A2, use Exercise 8, we see that for all λ∈F, we have λv+(1−λ)w∈A1 and λv+(1−λ)w∈A2, thus λv+(1−λ)w∈A1∩A2, use Exercise 8 again, we see that A1∩A2 is an affine subset.

                                            10

                                            Prove that the intersection of every collection of affine subsets of V is either an affine subset of V or the empty set.

                                            Proof: Let {Am} be a collection of affine subsets of V. Let A=∩mAm. If A=∅ there is nothing to prove. If A contains only one vector a∈V then A=a+{0} which is an affine subset. Suppose A contains more than two vectors, choose v,w∈A, then we have v,w∈Ai for all i, thus

                                            λv+(1−λ)w∈Ai for all i,∀λ∈F

                                            which means λv+(1−λ)w∈A for all λ∈F. so A is an affine subset of V by Exercise 8.

                                            11

                                            Suppose v1,…,vm∈V. Let

                                            A={λ1v1+⋯+λmvm:λ1,…,λm∈F,λ1+⋯+λm=1}.

                                            (a) Prove that A is an affine subset of V.

                                            (b) Prove that every affine subset of V that contains v1,…,vm also contains A.

                                            (c) Prove that A=v+U for some v∈V and some subspace U of V with dim⁡U≤m−1.

                                            Proof:

                                            (a) Let v,w∈A, then we can find scalars a1,⋯,am and b1,⋯,bm, such that

                                            v=a1v1+⋯+amvm,w=b1v1+⋯+bmvm

                                            and ∑ai=∑bi=1. Consider λv+(1−λ)w for any λ∈F, we have

                                            λv+(1−λ)w=λ∑k=1nakvk+(1−λ)∑k=1nbkvk=∑k=1n[λak+(1−λ)bk]vk

                                            since

                                            ∑k=1n[λak+(1−λ)bk]=λ∑k=1nak+(1−λ)∑k=1nbk=λ+(1−λ)=1

                                            we can have λv+(1−λ)w∈A, thus A is an affine subset of V by Exercise 8.

                                            (b) Since V is an affine subset, we can write V=v0+U for some v0∈V and U a subspace of V. Let u1,…,um∈U such that vi=v0+ui for i=1,…,m, let ∀a∈A, then we can find λ1,…,λm∈F,λ1+⋯+λm=1, such that a=λ1v1+⋯+λmvm. Now we have

                                            a=∑k=1mλkvk=∑k=1mλk(v0+uk)=(∑k=1mλk)v0+∑k=1mλkuk=v0+∑k=1mλkuk

                                            since U is a subspace, we have ∑k=1mλkuk∈U, thus a∈V, which means A⊆V.

                                            (c) Any vector a∈A can be written as a=∑k=1mλkvk, write λ1=1−∑k=2mλk, then

                                            a=(1−∑k=2mλk)v1+∑k=2mλkvk=v1−∑k=2mλk(vk−v1)

                                            let v=v1 and U be the subspace spanned by v2−v1,…,vm−v1, then dim⁡U≤m−1, and we have A=v+U.

                                            12

                                            Suppose U is a subpsace of V such that V/U is finite-dimensional. Prove that V is isomorphic to U×(V/U).

                                            Proof: As V/U is finite-dimensional, we select a basis of V/U to be v1+U,…,vm+U, then v1,…,vm must be linearly independent in V, and each vi∉U, otherwise vi+U=0 in V/U, contradicting v1+U,…,vm+U being independent in V/U.

                                            Define T:U×(V/U) as follows: for any v∈V, we have v+U∈V/U, thus there exists a1,…,am∈F such that v+U=∑k=1mak(vk+U), which means v−∑k=1makvk∈U. Let Tv=(v−∑k=1nakvk,π(v)). It is easy to verify T∈L(V,U×(V/U)).

                                            To see T is injective, let Tv=(0,0+U), then π(v)=0+U means v∈U and a1=⋯=am=0, thus v=0.

                                            To see T is surjective, let (u0,v0+U) be any element in U×(V/U), then we can find scalars c1,…,cm∈F such that v0+U=∑k=1mck(vk+U), let v=u0+∑k=1mckvk∈V, then π(v)=v+U=∑k=1mckvk+U=∑k=1mck(vk+U)=v0+U, which gives

                                            Tv=(v−∑k=1mckvk,π(v))=(u0,v0+U)

                                            13

                                            Suppose U is a subspace of V and v1+U,…,vm+U is a basis of V/U and u1…,un is a basis of U. Prove that v1,…,vm,u1,…,un is a basis of V.

                                            Proof: Let ∀v∈V, then v+U∈V/U, thus there are scalars c1,…,cm such that

                                            v+U=∑i=1mci(vi+U)=∑i=1mcivi+U⟹v−∑i=1mcivi∈U

                                            so there are scalars b1,…,bn such that v−∑i=1mcivi=∑j=1nbjuj, which means v is a linear combination of v1,…,vm,u1,…,un, thus the list v1,…,vm,u1,…,un spans V.

                                            Next let a1,…,am+n be scalars such that ∑i=1maivi+∑j=1nam+juj=0, let π be the quotient map from V to V/U, then

                                            U=0+U=π(∑i=1maivi+∑j=1nam+juj)=∑i=1maiπ(vi)=∑i=1mai(vi+U)

                                            since v1+U,…,vm+U is a basis of V/U, we have a1=⋯=am=0, this gives ∑j=1nam+juj=0, which means am+1=⋯=am+n=0. Thus v1,…,vm,u1,…,un is linearly independent.

                                            14

                                            Suppose U={(x1,x2,…)∈F∞:xj≠0 for only finitely many j}.

                                            (a) Show that U is a subspace of F∞.

                                            (b) Prove that F∞/U is infinite-dimensional.

                                            Solution:

                                            (a) Obviously 0=(0,0,…)∈U. If u,v∈U, then u and v both have only finitely many nonzero coordinates, thus u+v and λu have only finitely nonzero coordinates. It follows that U is a subpace.

                                            (b) To be done

                                             

                                            15

                                            Suppose φ∈L(V,F) and φ≠0. Prove that dim⁡V/(null φ)=1.

                                            Proof: Since φ≠0 there exists v0∈V such that φ(v0)=c≠0. If v∈V and φ(v)≠0, then

                                            φ(v)=φ(v)cc=φ(v)cφ(v0)⟹v−φ(v)φ(v0)v0∈null φ⟹v+U=φ(v)φ(v0)(v0+U)

                                            thus v0+U spans V/(null φ). Since v0∉null φ, we have v0+U≠0 in V/(null φ).

                                            16

                                            Suppose U is a subspace of V such that dim⁡V/U=1. Prove that there exists φ∈L(V,F) such that null φ=U.

                                            Proof: Let v0+U be a basis of V/U, then ∀v∈V, we have v+U=c(v0+U) for some c∈F, so v−cv0∈U, define φ:V→F such that φ(v)=c.

                                            We verify φ is a linear map: Let v=0, then 0+U=cv0+U, which means cv0∈U, so we must have c=0, otherwise it will lead to v0∈U and v0+U=U. Next for v1,v2∈V, we have

                                            φ(v1+v2)(v0+U)=v1+v2+U=v1+U+v2+U=φ(v1)(v0+U)+φ(v2)(v0+U)

                                            thus we have [φ(v1+v2)−φ(v1)−φ(v2)]v0∈U, which gives φ(v1+v2)=φ(v1)+φ(v2). Similarly, for v∈V we have φ(λv)(v0+U)=λv+U=λ(v+U)=λφ(v)(v0+U), thus φ(λv)=λφ(v).

                                            We then show null φ=U. If u∈U, then u+U=U=0v0+U, thus φ(u)=0 and U⊆null φ. If v∈V and φ(v)=0, then v+U=U, which shows v∈U and null φ⊆U.

                                            17

                                            Suppose U is a subspace of V such that V/U is finite-dimensional. Prove that there exists a subpsace W of V such that dim⁡W=dim⁡V/U and V=U⊕W.

                                            Proof: As V/U is finite-dimensional, we select a basis of V/U to be v1+U,…,vm+U, then v1,…,vm must be linearly independent in V, and each vi∉U, otherwise vi+U=0 in V/U, contradicting v1+U,…,vm+U being independent in V/U.

                                            Let W be the subspace of V spanned by v1,…,vm, then obviously dim⁡W=dim⁡V/U. For any v∈V, we can find c1,…,cm such that v+U=∑i=1mci(vi+U), thus v−∑i=1mcivi∈U, which means we can express v=v−∑i=1mcivi+∑i=1mcivi, so V=U+W. Let a∈U∩W, then a=∑i=1maivi for scalars a1,…,am, and in the quotient space V/U, we have 0+U=a+U=∑i=1maivi+U=∑i=1mai(vi+U), which shows a1=⋯=am=0, thus a=0.

                                            18

                                            Suppose T∈L(V,W) and U is a subspace of V. Let π denote the quotient map from V onto V/U. Prove that there exists S∈L(V/U,W) such that T=S∘π if and only if U⊂null T.

                                            Proof: (Necessity) Let u∈U, then Tu=S(π(u)), since null π=U and S is a linear map, we see that π(u)=0 in V/U and S(π(u))=0 in W. Thus Tu=0 and U⊂null T.

                                            (Sufficiency) If U⊂null T, then v+U⊂v+null T, or V/U⊂V/(null T), let S=T~ on V/U, then S is a linear map, and (S∘π)v=S(π(v))=S(v+U)=Tv by definition.

                                            19

                                            Find a correct statement analogous to 3.78 that is applicable to finite sets, with unions analogous to sums of subspaces and disjoint unions analogous to direct sums.

                                            Solution: Suppose S1,…,Sm are finite sets, then S1,…,Sm are disjoint if and only if

                                            card(S1∪⋯∪Sm)=card(S1)+⋯+card(Sm)

                                            20

                                            Suppose U is a subspace of V. Define Γ:L(V/U,W)→L(V,W) by Γ(S)=S∘π. Show that

                                            (a) Γ is a linear map.

                                            (b) Γ is injective.

                                            (c) range Γ={T∈L(V,W):Tu=0 for every u∈U}.

                                            Proof:

                                            (a) Let S0 be the zero linear map in L(V/U,W), then S0(v+U)=0 for any affine set v+U. So Γ(S0)v=S0(π(v))=S0(v+U)=0 for any v∈V, thus Γ(S0)=0.

                                            Let S1,S2 be elements in L(V/U,W), then for any v∈V we have

                                            Γ(S1+S2)v=(S1+S2)(v+U)=S1(v+U)+S2(v+U)=S1(π(v))+S2(π(v))

                                            which means Γ(S1+S2)=Γ(S1)+Γ(S2), similarly we can show Γ(λS)=λΓ(S).

                                            (b) Suppose Γ(S)=0 for some S, then S(π(v))=0 for any v∈V, or S(v+U)=0 for any v∈V, this means S is the zero linear map in L(V/U,W).

                                            (c) Let {T∈L(V,W):Tu=0 for every u∈U}=A, given any S∈L(V/U,W), we have Γ(S)u=S(π(u))=S(0+U)=0, thus range Γ⊂A.

                                            Conversely, given any T∈A, we know T∈L(V,W) and U⊂null T. Let S be defined with S(v+U)=Tv for v+U∈V/U. To show the definition of S makes sence, suppose v,v′∈V are such that v+U=v′+U, then v−v′∈U and T(v−v′)=0, hence Tv=Tv′. To show S is a linear map, we first see that S(0+U)=S(u+U) for u∈U, thus Tu=0 means S(0+U)=0. For v+U,v′+U∈V/U, we have

                                            S(v+U+v′+U)=S(v+v′+U)=T(v+v′)=Tv+Tv′=S(v+U)+S(v′+U)

                                            and similarly we have S(λ(v+U))=λS(v+U). Thus S∈L(V/U,W). Finally, we have

                                            Γ(S)v=S(π(v))=S(v+U)=Tv⟹Γ(S)=T

                                            this shows A⊂range Γ.
